newsitem.title: NEPAL: World Bank to fund Nepal water project.
newsitem.headline: World Bank to fund Nepal water project.

text.p: The World Bank will lend Nepal $18.2 million to set up a project to make drinking water available to at least half a million people in rural areas, officials said on Wednesday.

The money from the International Development Association (IDA) will be spent through community-based non-governmental organisations in small villages with populations of less than 500 people, they said.
The bank said in a statement the project aims at providing safe drinking water to 550,000 people in rural areas.
"This is the first loan assistance provided by the World Bank after it cancelled support to Arun III," said Madhav Prasad Ghimire, a spokesman for the Finance Ministry.
Last year, the World Bank shelved plans to lend $175 million to build a hydroelectric project in the Arun Valley in east Nepal following opposition by environmental groups.
Piped water is available to 64 percent of the kingdom's 21 million people. But Nepal plans to provide safe drinking water to all in five years.
